title: The Continuing Metamorphosis of the Web
segmentation: I'm very pleased to introduce today's keynote speaker who is Doctor Alfred Spector and Doctor Specter is currently the Vice President of Research and Special initiatives at Google, and he's had a very distinguished career both in industry and academia before he was at Google.
He was also a VP at IBM.
He had multiple vice presidencies there and in addition to that, he was.
He was the founder and CEO of Trans Arc as well as a professor at CMU.
So Alfred has many distinguished honors, including he received the Sutomo, Award for work in scalable architectures in computers.
Scalable architectures and distributed systems.
This is one of the IEEE Computer Society's most distinguished awards.
He's also a fellow.
Both the IEEE and ACM, as well as a member of the National Academy of Engineering and most recently, just this past week, he was was appointed a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
And he's going to be talking to us today about the continuing metamorphosis of the web.
It's a pleasure to be here.
I was a last at this conference in Honolulu in 2002.
I'll make an occasional reference to my presentation there.
This talk comes about for a number of reasons, but mostly I I'm always fascinated by how is it that we make the big advances in our field.
Is it that we all get together and decide on sort of the ultimately greatest single project and understand its implications and then go do it?

Or do we have a general idea about how the world of science and technology, particularlly, computer science and information technology should progress and somehow or other we collectively get together and work on individual elements within some broad framework and then we find out that after a certain amount of time we've achieved an enormous amount.
I think the latter is usually the approach that works and one can see the really highly architected projects often not succeeding, and there are many, many examples of where that happened.
The web is clearly an example of 1 where they were very good ideas initially that have then metamorphosized into really impressive results.
The question is, can we see what's going on today and can we see what those results really will be in the future from our collective work?
Azaka
Unity, So what I'm going to talk about is how I see the web.

As a very good exemplar of that pattern, and then look at what I think are following from our evolutionary path, the major advances that are brewing today and you're going to hear me talk about totally transparent processing.
The rule of distributed computing and hybrid, not artificial intelligence.
I think it's incumbent upon folks that are in the industrial world to make sure that in academic conferences, we tell you what we think are the important research problems.
And I will do that at the conclusion of this.
So that being said, you all know what Google is about.
I won't read our mission statement for the four millionth time.

What I will say, though, in what you may not realize is the succinct statement about research at Google is that I think were organized and optimized for in situ, or if you will invite in vivo work work where we can exploit the opportunities to do empirical work with a large base of users and a very large base of data.
So many of the folks have wondered why we're not organized with quite as much differentiation between research and engineering.
Why there's a broader flow back and forth, why people for do multiple roles at Google?
That's because.

It's another kind of a search problem similar to the search problem you do when you actually form the query and then want to get the data back so it's an interesting challenge, but a new frontier in web search.
Voice Search is one that's bubbling up now, so this is clearly voice to text, voice to image, voice to video.
It's working remarkably well.
It's very interesting that for the last, I don't know 10 years of my career I've been working with voice recognition teams looking to see what the killer application will be for voice.
Clearly there have been customer self help, self help applications and industry to try to avoid these hierarchical DTMF based call trees.
That one deals with that everybody hates and that's been to some degree successful, but we haven't really found all of the applications of voice that we would have thought we would have.
Given the decades of work that's gone into voice recognition, I think it's been very slow going.
I think now, and I'll say it publicly.
I think voice search is a killer app for voice.
And it's to the point of quality that it's really good now and I use it as the dominant interface to Google on my Google Phone.

My last point.
Is what I refer to as hybrid not artificial intelligence?

So despite the fact that I did my PhD work in systems when I was at Stanford in a period when there was tremendous focus on AI and I used to spend a lot of time at the AI lab across Route 280 from the main campus many years ago.
I didn't go into the field, but I always thought it was the most interesting field and I still do.
What what I've seen in AI is.
I've looked at it a little bit from a distance and then had the pleasure of leading researchers that are arguably AI researchers.
Is that AI is done best when it's focused on particularly specific problem domains rather than general domains?
Is done better when AI doesn't require a perfect solution as good as the best human.
And when the problems that are solved using AI are.
Extension extending the capability of people rather than supplanting or replacing the capability of people.
Now this isn't to say that we haven't built a computer system.
That's the best chess player in the world we have.
It isn't to say that computers can't do things that people can't.
Of course they can, but I think where we have done best in AI is when we have this hybrid model of people.

Helping the computer systems, teaching them, using them in the computer systems, then helping people in a virtuous circle, and I think that's been valuable, and it's where I think we should be primarily focusing at this point, extending the capability of people not in isolation and focusing on specific problem domains, so we've seen it on the web.
Again, the web is aggregated so many users that we can get user responses from a vast population.
All those responses, if you will.
Helping the cloud helping the system.
Helping the web in a broad sense.
Examples are feedback and IR and machine learning of many forms.

All of the speech, Reco and machine translation are fueled by that, so it's another example of sort of bottom up successes of seeing lots of individual things in in AI that come to be valuable solving specific problems.
I think it's led to a new kind of design paradigm in the field.
It used to be when I started out.
I thought of myself as a computer architect.
What is the architecture of the computer system?
And yeah, we know their human factors will get the human factor requirements in and then we'll build the system.
Today I think we look at.
The human community.
The vast number of users in the human community and the software and say how can we build something that combines the capability of the machines and the people to build something of great value.
And I suspect most of you in this room think about problems in that way today.
It's not.

How do I build it in conjunction with the user community?
We're now sort of designers over the broader space.
